BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs to be found in particular at intermediate and high altitudes can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The soft wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
Along the border with France On steep north, northeast and east facing slopes the avalanche danger is higher.
In particular on very steep sunny slopes and in steep rocky terrain medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack. At elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low altitude only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the northwesterly wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep north, northeast and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
Along the border with Switzerland On shady slopes the avalanche danger is higher.
In the regions with a lot of snow and on very steep sunny slopes small and medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the northwesterly wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from northwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude. Especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls: Fresh wind slabs are in many cases small but to be assessed with care and prudence, in particular on very steep slopes.

As a consequence of solar radiation only isolated avalanches are possible. Especially in steep rocky terrain and on sunny slopes small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 cm of snow, and up to 20 cm in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. The wind slabs have bonded generally well with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level. As a consequence of a moderate to strong northwesterly wind, soft wind slabs will form in the course of the day in some localities.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can in some places be released by large loads and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Wind slabs can be released, mostly by large loads and reach large size in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large surface-area wind slabs of last week remain in some cases prone to triggering above approximately 2200 m. These are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from northwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude. Fresh wind slabs are in many cases small but to be assessed with care and prudence.

As a consequence of solar radiation only isolated avalanches are possible. Especially in steep rocky terrain and on sunny slopes small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly.
The old snowpack is hard. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase during the day. As a consequence of a moderate to strong northwesterly wind, soft wind slabs will form in the course of the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: By Sunday wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of wind, clearly visible wind slabs will form. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of last week are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads. In gullies and bowls a considerable avalanche danger will persist in some regions.
In particular at the base of rock walls and on very steep sunny slopes individual mostly small snow slides are possible as a consequence of solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: By Sunday wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of wind, clearly visible wind slabs will form. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In these regions the avalanche situation is generally favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on northwest to east to southeast facing aspects and generally at elevated altitudes. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain.
In particular in the regions with a lot of snow and on sunny slopes more small and medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. These can occur in particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last six days. The snowpack will be well bonded below approximately 2000 m.
In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. Caution is to be exercised in all aspects in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a gathering strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places. The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. They are unlikely to be released now.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of last week are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. Especially on wind-loaded slopes and on steep slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular in the Prealps below approximately 2100 m. Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. Caution is to be exercised in all aspects in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a gathering strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places. The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. They but unlikely to be released now.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be quite favourable.
Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches are not to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack is not distinctly layered. The weather conditions will foster a stabilisation of the weak layers in all aspects. Avalanches are not to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.
